content:
Hello folks!

I wrote an article with an attempt to some kind of statistical analysis of usage of Clippy by Rust developers. This is my first text on this topic so far so I would greatly appreciate any feedback.

https://medium.com/monocodus/a-survey-into-static-analyzers-configurations-clippy-for-rust-part-1-5de50fd9326

Does it represent the case well? Do you find it interesting? What should I do another way?

Thanks :smiley:

Clippy is “A collection of links to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.” >

Clippy is “A collection of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.”

This research is relay important and thank you for getting started on it.
2 thoughts, as someone that has contributed to a bunch of rust code in the past 5 years. As I have seen it, most projects do not use clippy, and meny that do configure it inline, like https://github.com/rust-lang/cargo/blob/master/src/cargo/lib.rs#L5-L31
So I don't know that not having a .clippy means that the defaults are good.

oliver said:

Clippy is “A collection of links to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.” >

Clippy is “A collection of lints to catch common mistakes and improve your Rust code.”

Oh, Thank you!

Silly mistake, fixed =)
hmm, this article mentions complexity lints a lot, but complexity lints are not really why I use clippy (I find them kind of annoying)
clippy is good for 'you rewrote this standard library function' and things like that
or 'you wrote valid code that will crash at runtime': https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/75671
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/78825#discussion_r519057758 also has some discussion on the purpose of clippy
